author: By ‘Sway'
title: Are We Ready for Putin’s Cyber War? I Asked One of Biden’s Top Cybersecurity Officials.
description: Anne Neuberger, the deputy national security adviser for cyber and emerging technology, discusses how the battle in cyberspace is shaping up.
content: Ever since Russian forces invaded Ukraine late last month, President Biden has been toeing a fine line between providing support to the Ukrainians and averting kinetic, nuclear and cyber conflict between superpowers. In this conversation, Anne Neuberger, the deputy national security adviser for cyber and emerging technology, unpacks how this conflict is evolving in the cyber realm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘The Exorcism of God’ Review: Devilishly Demeaning
description: In this regressive tale of demons and damsels, a priest must admit his sins before he can vanquish a malevolent spirit.
content: “The Exorcism of God” opens with the possession of Magali (Irán Castillo), a nun at an orphanage in Mexico whose nipples get at least as much on-screen attention as her face. As soon as Magali and Father Peter Williams (Will Beinbrink), the priest performing her exorcism, are left alone, he rapes her. Such is the nature of this soulless film, directed by Alejandro Hidalgo and written by Hidalgo and Santiago Fernández Calvete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How the “Encanto” Soundtrack Became a Smash’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how fans drove the album to the top of the charts. Then they will make their own TikTok video in response to the global hit.
content: Featured Article: “How the ‘Encanto’ Soundtrack Became a Smash” by Ben Sisario
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here are the latest developments in the war on Ukraine.
description: The top diplomats from Ukraine and Russia failed to reach an agreement on Thursday to calm the fighting in Ukraine or even to ease the worsening humanitarian crisis, dashing hopes for a swift end to a two-week-old conflict that has killed hundreds and displaced millions.

author: By David Waldstein
title: Coached by an Enigmatic Russian, China Emerges as a Sled Hockey Power
description: Only five years after creating the program, China’s team has reached the semifinal round at the Beijing Paralympics. Players credit their little-known coach as their “spiritual support.”
content: BEIJING — All the Russian athletes were kicked out of the Paralympics before the Games began last week, but there is still a Russian here, and he has a chance to win a medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘‘I Must Save My Mom’: The Women Returning to Ukraine’
description: How has the Russian invasion of Ukraine affected ordinary citizens?
content: The Russian invasion has upended the lives of 44 million Ukrainians. More than two million Ukrainians have fled to neighboring countries, according to the United Nations. A million more have been internally displaced. Aid groups have described it as one of the biggest humanitarian crises in recent memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski and Shashank Bengali
title: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
description: The top diplomats of Russia and Ukraine failed to make even a hint of progress Thursday in their first face-to-face meeting since the Russian invasion began, while Russian bombardments spread more carnage in a two-week-old war that Ukraine estimated had already caused $100 billion in damage.The fighting has deepened suffering in the country, especially in besieged cities like Mariupol in the southeast and Chernihiv in the north. Russians forces also were reported to have gained ground in some smaller cities near Kyiv, the capital.

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Makes Slow Advances
description: Talks in Turkey ended without agreement.
content: Russian forces were making slow advances in Ukraine on Thursday as high-level talks failed to yield progress on ending the war or even brokering a temporary cease-fire. Here are the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: The New Financial Supermarkets
description: Private-equity firms were once niche players serving big clients. Now they’re trying to be everything to everyone.
content: Three decades ago, Jonathan Gray might have been an unlikely candidate to become Blackstone’s president and expected successor to its chief executive, Stephen A. Schwarzman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Last Exit: Space’ Review: Not-So-Final Frontiers
description: The director Rudolph Herzog, with his father, Werner Herzog, narrating, explores the feasibility of off-world colonization.
content: In the documentary “Last Exit: Space,” the director Rudolph Herzog grabs a baton from his father, Werner Herzog, and continues his dad’s explorations of oddball aspiring visionaries. The topic is space colonization: who might do it and how, and, ultimately, what reaching for the stars says about living on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Customer’s Racial Slur Drew a Fatal Punch. The Sentence Is House Arrest.
description: A plea deal in a confrontation at a Dunkin’ shop in Tampa, Fla., “holds the defendant accountable while considering the totality of the circumstances,” the prosecutor said.
content: A Black manager of a Dunkin’ shop in Tampa, Fla., who fatally punched a 77-year-old white customer last year after he repeatedly used a racial slur in addressing him was sentenced this week to two years of house arrest, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Facing economic calamity, Putin talks of nationalizing Western businesses.
description: With the ruble collapsing, the economy contracting and people abandoning the country, Russia’s leader talks of a Western plot to destroy the country.
content: Besieged by an onslaught of sanctions that have largely undone 30 years of economic integration with the West in the space of two weeks, President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday opened the door to nationalizing the assets of Western companies pulling out of Russia and exhorted senior officials to “act decisively” to preserve jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Modern-Day Moses
description: This is a man on the grandest of missions: to save this country from itself, to insist that morality ought to decide policy.
content: The Rev. William Barber II is a large man, but bent. He walks with a cane, with his helper nearby, placing each step with deliberation to make sure that his footing is sure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Karen Joy Fowler’s Grandfather Lied His Way Into a Who’s Who
description: “In fact, his appearance in this book may have been his greatest single achievement.”
content: “In fact, his appearance in this book may have been his greatest single achievement,” says the author Karen Joy Fowler, whose latest novel is “Booth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Former San Jose State Trainer Is Charged With Violating Athletes
description: The charges in Federal District Court came after the Justice Department found Title IX violations at the university.
content: A former athletic trainer at San Jose State University was accused Thursday of violating the civil rights of four women he was supposed to be treating for injuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Christine Hauser
title: 660 U.S. Place Names Include a Slur for Native Women. Change Is Coming.
description: The Interior Department is asking tribes for help finding new names for mountains, rivers and other landmarks that include the offensive term “squaw.”
content: The map dots, resembling a scattergram of America, point to snow-covered pinnacles, remote islands and places in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: Samuel L. Jackson and Walter Mosley Team Up for a Sci-Fi Fable
description: In a joint interview, the actor and writer discuss “The Last Days of Ptolemy Grey,” their “fairy tale” about an old man negotiating dementia and family drama with the help of a wonder drug.
content: Samuel L. Jackson made his name in the movies, Walter Mosley in literature. But when it was time for these two arts legends to collaborate, they knew television was the only medium that would work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | March 16, 2022
description: How have extreme temperatures in the United States changed over time?
content: Special Announcement for March: The American Statistical Association is now running its annual This is Statistics Spring Contest. source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Everything Here Is Tabboo!
description: Four decades into his art career, the painter Stephen Tashjian, a.k.a. Tabboo!, a downtown drag personage, has suddenly found success at an age when many are collecting Social Security.
content: So much has changed and so radically about New York over the 40 years since the artist Stephen Tashjian — best known by his drag moniker, Tabboo! — first took occupancy on his light-filled walk-up in a stolid apartment house called the Mildred that it is hard to believe that, back in 1982, his was one of just three buildings standing on his stretch of East Fifth Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: A Labor Movement for the Artists Who Make Popular Culture Move
description: “Why are we not working together to fix our problems?” Entertainment-industry choreographers are uniting to address long-simmering issues.
content: The entertainment industry is in the midst of a dance boom. Steven Spielberg’s “West Side Story” and HBO’s “Euphoria” are using dance to drive storytelling; TikTok dance challenges are propelling songs up the Billboard charts. “Everywhere you turn — on TV, in film and on the internet — there’s dance everywhere,” said the veteran choreographer and director Vincent Paterson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Playing in the FM Band’ Review: A Free-Form Radio Legend
description: The trailer for this documentary shows today’s New Yorkers saying they had never heard of Steve Post. The film itself tries to make a case that they ought to have.
content: Taking its title from a book written by its subject, “Playing in the FM Band: The Steve Post Story” memorializes Post, a New York radio personality who, the movie insists, helped define what became known as free-form radio — a kind of programming without a strict format, in which the D.J. chooses the music and riffs on whatever they like, often soliciting call-in listener responses — beginning at the FM station WBAI in the late 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Feasts for Lazy Cooks
description: And one project recipe to get you back in the cooking groove.
content: Look, sometimes I fall into a cooking rut, or I get too busy or overwhelmed to go shop, or — let’s be honest — I turn into a sluggish, unimaginative creature, incapable of thinking beyond the hour or so in front of me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The war in Ukraine is likely to slow global growth, the I.M.F. warns.
description: The economic fallout from Russia’s invasion will depend on the outcome of the war and the duration of the sanctions.
content: The war in Ukraine and the associated sanctions that countries around the world have imposed on Russia are likely to cause a downgrade of the International Monetary Fund’s global economic growth forecast, Kristalina Georgieva, the I.M.F.’s managing director, said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: In recent years, Tyler, the Creator has won a Grammy, had two albums make their debut atop the Billboard 200 and earned heaps of critical praise. But even for such an accomplished rapper and singer, playing Madison Square Garden is still a point of pride. He brings it up more than once on last year’s “Call Me if You Get Lost,” a brisk, boastful and occasionally melancholic album that takes aesthetic cues from mid-2000s rap mixtapes (including hypeman services rendered by DJ Drama). On the record’s lead single, Tyler boasts of his “M.S.G. sellout,” as well as his car collection and his credit score.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: While Writing a Future Best Seller, Give It Room to Breathe
description: Nina de Gramont tends to take a break from a book in progress. With “The Christie Affair,” that marination — and Reese Witherspoon — made all the difference.
content: DAME GAME Nina de Gramont is the author of eight books — four for young adult readers and four for grown-ups — but her latest novel, “The Christie Affair,” is her first New York Times best seller. “If this had happened when I was 25, I’d think that it meant I was really brilliant,” she said in a phone interview. “Happening at 55, I know it means I’m really lucky. So I’m appreciating it, for sure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Onstage, the French Election Is a Landslide Win for Cynicism
description: As the presidential vote approaches, theaters and comedy venues are addressing the campaign. Many shows reach a similar conclusion: Don’t trust politicians.
content: PARIS — If elections are spectacles, France’s presidential campaign, caught between voter apathy and war in Europe, has so far struggled to connect with its audience. Yet on French stages, a number of artists are making hay out of the upcoming vote — and the picture is hardly flattering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert: Major Food Brands Are ‘Russian’ for the Exits
description: “Yesterday, Coca-Cola and Pepsi announced that they will suspend business in Russia. Your move, Shasta!” Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imogen West-Knights
title: Remembering Avicii by Stepping Into His Bewildering World
description: The Avicii Experience offers a taste of the pressures that led up to the D.J.’s death. It’s the latest immersive exhibition trying to find the line between emotional engagement and entertainment.
content: STOCKHOLM — Visitors filed one by one into a dark, 6 foot by 12 foot room at the Space exhibition center here last Friday, where they were greeted by a mix of ringing and muddled noises: camera clicks, audience cheers, plane engine roars. Strobe lights bounced off a ceiling-high screen showing the interiors of cars, paparazzi flashes and the reaching arms of a festival crowd in quick succession. Jagged mirrors in the ceiling reflected the chaos below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Gustavo Dudamel Could Be the New York Philharmonic’s Future
description: As the orchestra searches for a new leader, this superstar conductor led the first of two programs pairing Schumann symphonies with new works.
content: On Wednesday, when the New York Philharmonic and Lincoln Center hosted a news conference announcing that the $550 million renovation of David Geffen Hall had been fully funded and that it would reopen this fall, Jaap van Zweden, the orchestra’s music director, was not in town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Griffin
title: As Museums Become Her Ally, Suzanne Lacy Brings Her Activism Inside
description: From Queens, N.Y., to Manchester, England, museums are learning from this artist, who creates spaces where other voices can be raised.
content: LOS ANGELES — On a cold day last December, sitting outside her studio in Santa Monica, Calif., the artist Suzanne Lacy talked excitedly about the coming year. In Manchester, England, exhibitions of her work were already open at the Whitworth Art Gallery and the Manchester Art Gallery. She looked forward to a prestigious fellowship at the University of Manchester in the spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: In a reversal, Uniqlo’s owner pulls out of Russia.
description: Tadashi Yanai, the founder of Fast Retailing, had faced backlash for his decision to stay in Russia.
content: In an about-face, Fast Retailing, the clothing giant that owns Uniqlo, said on Thursday that the brand would stop operating in Russia. Just days earlier, the company’s founder had said it would continue to do business in the country, drawing backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Mujib Mashal
title: Modi’s Party Wins the Biggest Prize in India’s State Elections
description: Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state, is staying in the Bharatiya Janata Party’s hands, as the party maintains its electoral success despite mounting economic hardship.
content: LUCKNOW, India — Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s national governing party won re-election in India’s most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, on Thursday, continuing the party’s record of repeated success at the polls despite mounting economic hardship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Alan Feuer and Adam Bednar
title: Truckers gather near Washington to protest pandemic restrictions, without creating much disruption.
description: A caravan of semis, pickups and R.V.s that had driven across the United States to protest vaccine mandates and other Covid restrictions reached the capital region this week, but as the convoy circled the city, downtown Washington was business as usual.

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Vacant Homes Everywhere
description: Census surveys reveal U.S. vacancy rates, but applying the data to a home search or to social issues is complex.
content: At a time when household units are forming faster than homes are being built and many Americans can’t find a home at all, it may come as a surprise that nearly one in 10 American homes — more than 16 million in all — were “vacant” when the 2020 census was recorded. In some states, the vacancy rate exceeded 20 percent. What can we make of these figures? A recent post by LendingTree attempts to parse the data by comparing vacancy rates in all 50 states, the basis of this week’s chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gladys Carrión and Vincent Schiraldi
title: We’ve Tried Juveniles as Adults Before. The Results Were Catastrophic.
description: New York City’s mayor wants to return to a failed policy.
content: In 2010, 16-year-old Kalief Browder was jailed on New York’s notorious Rikers Island, accused of stealing a backpack, a charge he consistently denied. Bail was set at $3,000, a sum his family could not afford. He spent the next three years there awaiting his day in court, including two years in solitary confinement. He suffered abuse by corrections officers and inmates, and he attempted suicide. In 2013, the charges were dropped. Two years after his release, he committed suicide in his parents’ apartment in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russian forces are laying siege to the northern Ukraine city of Chernihiv, the mayor says.
description: Ukrainian forces are battling to keep some roads open, as Russia tightens its cordon around the battered city. “We are surrounded,” the mayor said.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Russian forces have encircled and are laying siege to the ancient city of Chernihiv in northern Ukraine, the mayor said, adding that critical infrastructure for its 300,000 residents was rapidly failing as it came under repeated bombardment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Park
title: I’m Done Being Your Model Minority
description: As an American of Korean descent, I feel terrified for my life and the lives of those who look like me.
content: Growing up in New York City, I learned street smarts early. I kept my head down, my money in my sock and my mind on my business. At 12, I started riding the subway alone, and in high school I commuted four hours a day from Queens to the Bronx. When a classmate was slashed in the face by a stranger at our school’s subway stop, I still took the train home that day and every day after that. It takes a lot to faze me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The I.R.S. plans to hire 10,000 workers to clear a tax return backlog.
description: More than 20 million returns remain unprocessed, the agency said.
content: The Internal Revenue Service said on Thursday that it planned a hiring spree this tax season as it tries to clear a backlog of more than 20 million unprocessed tax returns from previous years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: United Airlines workers with vaccine exemptions can return to their regular jobs.
description: The updated policy affects 2,200 employees who have been on unpaid leave or in roles not requiring in-person contact with customers.
content: United Airlines, which was one of the first major businesses to mandate vaccination against the coronavirus, will allow workers who were granted religious or medical exemptions from receiving a shot to return to their jobs at the end of this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: The heavy toll of war on Ukraine.
content: The death, destruction and deprivation of war are mounting in Ukraine, from which an estimated two million people have fled seeking refuge. In the southern city of Mariupol, Russian commanders appear to be resorting to tactics used in Chechnya and Syria: flattening settlements with overwhelming and indiscriminate firepower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: A Two-Year, 50-Million-Person Experiment in Changing How We Work
description: The office was never one size fits all. It was one size fits some, with the expectation that everybody else would squeeze in.
content: Kristen Egziabher was all jitters just before the pandemic, awaiting news of a possible raise, until her manager came back dejected from his meeting with the higher-ups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Britain Freezes Assets of Roman Abramovich, Creating Crisis at Chelsea
description: The Premier League club will be allowed to continue operating, but it cannot sell tickets or merchandise and is blocked from buying or selling players.
content: LONDON — For Chelsea F.C.’s players and coaches, the first snippets of information arrived in the text messages and news alerts that pinged their cellphones as they made their way to a private terminal at London’s Gatwick Airport on Thursday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Ty Haney Is Doing Things Differently This Time
description: The Outdoor Voices founder has a new venture that aims to reward customers with blockchain-based assets. But do brand loyalists really want NFTs?
content: It would probably be a stretch to say that Ty Haney changed the way we work out. She didn’t start a boutique fitness craze; she’s not Jane Fonda. But Outdoor Voices, the athleisure company she founded in 2014, helped to popularize a fitness paradigm that has more to do with everyday movement than the body-stressing athleticism advertised by brands like Nike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Judge Will Review Lawyer’s Emails Sought by Jan. 6 Panel
description: A federal judge said he would decide whether emails to and from John Eastman should be released to the House committee investigating the attack on the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge said on Wednesday that he would review 111 emails that the lawyer John Eastman, an ally of former President Donald J. Trump, is attempting to keep from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, as the panel works to force the release of documents from lawyers involved in plans to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: An Exiled Theater With a Warning for Europe
description: The Belarus Free Theater’s members fled repression at home. The company’s latest show imagines a nightmare future of authoritarian Russian rule.
content: LONDON — When the players of the Belarus Free Theater began working on “Dogs of Europe” three years ago, they thought it was a play about a dystopia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Helping Women Survive Birth in a Pandemic
description: As the maternal mortality rate surged during the pandemic, Niulquie McKinney, a doula and midwife, turned her attention to the most vulnerable mothers-to-be.
content: As part of a weekly series on changes in the workplace for women, we’re profiling those who stepped up at a moment of crisis and filled gaps in the labor market during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rachel Quester, Michael Simon Johnson, Mooj Zadie, M.J. Davis Lin, Lisa Chow, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Inside Ukraine’s Embattled Cities
description: Dispatches on two cities in Ukraine’s south that are surrounded by Russian forces and under attack.
content: It has been two weeks since the beginning of the war in Ukraine and Russia’s high-tech army of nearly 200,000 soldiers has not taken control of any major cities, except the southern port of Kherson. The Ukrainian resistance has been too strong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘The Cherry Bushido’ Review: That Fighting Spirit
description: Japanese nationalism and religious faith fuel a battle in the spirit realm in this awkward martial-arts fantasy.
content: I’m positive I’ve never seen anything like “The Cherry Bushido.” It’s terrible — not even in a way that I tend to want from my demon-studded, karate-chopping, English-dubbed international-warfare polemics. But this movie means every speech about the power of religious faith and the restoration of Japanese might (and boy, are there plenty of those). It’s not kidding about every slash of samurai sword, either, even though most of those are awkward, too. I’m talking about the kind of entertainment where as soon as three young women in martial-arts robes stand poised for action, back-to-back-to-back, on comes a piano-kissed rock song that this stationary bike of a movie suddenly summons the zest to pedal hard to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Approves $13.6 Billion in Emergency Aid for Ukraine
description: Bipartisan backing for the assistance provided momentum for a broader, $1.5 trillion measure to fund the government through September.
content: WASHINGTON — The $1.5 trillion spending bill that passed the House on Wednesday was fueled in large part by bipartisan support for an emergency aid package for Ukraine, which would steer $13.6 billion in military and humanitarian assistance to the war-torn country under assault by Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘I Am Here’ Review: A Holocaust Survivor Reckons With Her Pain
description: Decades after experiencing some of the most nightmarish moments of World War II, a woman shares her stories.
content: “I Am Here” begins with a promise it does not entirely keep. Jordy Sank’s documentary about the Holocaust survivor Ella Blumenthal ends its opening montage depicting antisemitic acts with a talk radio host telling listeners about the open letter Blumenthal wrote to a social media Holocaust denier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: ‘You Murdered My Daughter’: Relatives of OxyContin Victims Confront the Sacklers
description: It was the first time, after years of lawsuits, that the family that owns Purdue Pharma heard directly from families who had lost loved ones to addiction.
content: “You murdered my daughter and destroyed my family,” said Donna Mazurek, whose daughter, Paige, was prescribed Purdue Pharma’s opioid painkiller OxyContin after a root canal, became addicted, spiraled into heroin and overdosed when she was 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Europe prepares for reverberations of war: a slower economy and faster inflation.
description: The European Central Bank is moving ahead with plans to end its bond-buying programs amid rising inflation.
content: Just as Europe was emerging from a downturn caused by the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, Russia’s war against Ukraine has sent energy prices soaring and shaken forecasts of the region’s economic health.

content: We’d like to learn more about how employers are monitoring and evaluating worker activity.

title: These Schools Will Require Masks Even After California’s Mandate Ends
description: Some of the state’s biggest districts, including Los Angeles Unified, won’t be lifting their school mask mandates this week.
content: Tomorrow marks a pandemic milestone: California will lift its classroom mask mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: These Small, Cheap Devices Help Monitor Haiti’s Earthquakes
description: When conventional seismometers in Haiti failed before the 2010 quake, less sophisticated devices operated by citizen scientists helped seismic researchers fill in the blanks.
content: When a magnitude-7.0 earthquake hit Haiti in 2010 and killed an estimated 200,000 people, there was only one working seismometer in the country. The shaking quickly overwhelmed the seismometer, an education instrument installed at a high school, and it recorded little useful data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Amid Murky Investigation, Key Defender Asks to Quit 9/11 Case
description: A defense lawyer who has spent a decade on the Guantánamo case abruptly sought to resign amid an in-house investigation.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A long-serving death penalty defense lawyer for one of the five men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks has asked to be removed from the case, stirring new uncertainty about when the trial might begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Who Gets the First Chance to Sell Marijuana in New York?
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul will announce a policy aimed at helping communities affected by the long war on drugs.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Let’s start with a question: Who can be a marijuana retailer in New York State? We’ll look at a wrinkle in the state’s plan that will vault some applicants to the front of the line. We’ll also look at an emotional outpouring among sweet tooths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mikhail Zygar
title: How Vladimir Putin Lost Interest in the Present
description: Does the  president of Russia have anyone who can tell him when he’s making a mistake?
content: Thanks to Vladimir Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine, Russia is now more isolated than it has ever been. The economy is under sanctions and international businesses are withdrawing. The news media has been even further restricted; what remains spouts paranoia, nationalism and falsehoods. The people will have increasingly less communication with others beyond their borders. And in all of this, I fear, Russia increasingly resembles its president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Dominique Morisseau Asks: ‘What Does Freedom Look Like Now?’
description: Her new play, “Confederates,” straddles two eras, exploring what liberation means to a present-day academic and an enslaved woman in the 1860s.
content: In 2016, Penumbra Theater and the Oregon Shakespeare Festival commissioned Dominique Morisseau to write a play as part of the American Revolutions: the United States History Cycle. The remit: to create a work about the Black experience of the Civil War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Americans Strongly Favor Moneymaking Deals for College Athletes, Poll Says
description: While consensus existed over college athletes being able to earn from endorsements, there were splits on gambling and paying player salaries.
content: Americans are divided over whether colleges should pay their athletes, but feel strongly that players should be paid for the use of their names, images and likenesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: After the Satan Shoes, Building a Sneaker Empire (Not Evil)
description: MSCHF has designs on your feet.
content: Last year, when MSCHF, the creative collective in Brooklyn that styles itself as the Banksy of consumer culture, unveiled its “Satan Shoes,” a collaboration with Lil Nas X featuring Nike Air Max 97s modified with a bit of blood and devilish symbolism, it sparked a firestorm of controversy as well as a Nike lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Scott
title: Thinking of Going to Southeast Asia? Here’s What to Expect.
description: As the once tourist-dependent region reopens its borders, travelers should expect more paperwork, higher airfares and cheaper hotels — at least for the short-term.
content: Their flights were more expensive and took longer, their favorite restaurant was shuttered and they had to take coronavirus tests on the first and fifth days of their trip. But the biggest hassle for Brian Lamberty and Paola Laird, retirees from London, in their long-awaited return to Phuket Island in Thailand was the paperwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Binyam
title: A 20th-Century Swede Doggedly Avoids Distinction
description: In Lena Andersson’s “Son of Svea,” one man devotes his life to the virtue of ordinariness — and mirrors the rise and fall of the Swedish social state.
content: SON OF SVEA A Tale of the People’s HomeBy Lena AnderssonTranslated by Sarah Death
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Microsoft’s Pursuit of Climate Goals Runs Into Headwinds
description: The company aims to be “carbon negative” by the end of the decade, but its emissions rose sharply in the most recent year measured.
content: Microsoft has an ambitious plan to cut its carbon emissions. But on Thursday, the company reported a big increase in the greenhouse gases emanating from its operations and its products, a reminder of the challenges that companies face as they try to clean up their businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: 12 Wines From Argentina and Chile to Seek Out
description: These distinctive wines show off the character and identity of South American terroirs.
content: For many years I rarely found an emotional connection to South American wines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Passes Bill to Bolster Protections for Women Facing Violence
description: The reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, a top priority of President Biden that expired in 2019, was included in a wide-ranging government spending bill.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday voted to renew a lapsed law aimed at preventing domestic violence, sexual assault and stalking, approving the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, a top priority of President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Tabboo! Paints a Valentine to New York City
description: A show in two downtown galleries surveys the Covid cityscapes of this multitalented artist, who has become one of the town’s best painters.
content: “Stop flitting around the house and take off that ridiculous outfit.” These words, the artist Stephen Tashjian says, were often directed his way in the Armenian American household of his childhood in Leicester, Mass., when he was already a young professional puppeteer as well as a busy multitasker. They were prophetic because in the early 1980s, fresh from art school in Boston, Tashjian would land in New York and within days begin his rise to fame — in costume — as a drag performance artist on the East Village art scene, at the Pyramid Club and other establishments of gay downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Offseason’ Review: Shuttered Island
description: A bereaved woman is trapped on a mysterious island in this atmospheric horror movie.
content: An island might seem an ideal setting for a horror movie — what’s scarier than having nowhere to run? — but restricted characters can also leave you with limited narrative options. “Offseason,” the latest feature from the writer and director Mickey Keating, is a good example: Despite a wonderfully eerie atmosphere, this moody examination of guilt and mourning is too generic to scare and too predictable to surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Conor Dougherty and Sophie Kasakove
title: Berkeley vs. Berkeley Is a Fight Over the California Dream
description: The state’s complex environmental laws are being weaponized in lawsuits against the University of California, Berkeley, which is under pressure to admit more and more students.
content: BERKELEY, Calif. — Kiara Bragg has spent years imagining herself at the University of California, Berkeley — walking through Sproul Plaza, navigating crowds of students, becoming the first in her working-class family to graduate from her state’s iconic flagship school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Police Officer’s Suicide After Jan. 6 Riot Is Ruled a Line-of-Duty Death
description: “If he did not go to work that day, he would be here,” said the widow of Officer Jeffrey Smith of the Metropolitan Police.
content: The death of Officer Jeffrey Smith, who killed himself nine days after confronting a mob at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was the direct result of an injury he sustained during the riot, a retirement board has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Turning Red’ Review: Beware the Red-Furred Monster
description: A 13-year-old girl becomes a red panda when she loses her cool in Domee Shi’s heartwarming but wayward coming-of-age film.
content: A quirky Asian teenager transforms into a giant red panda whenever she gets excited … even the premise gives me pause. Which makes the task of reviewing the new Disney/Pixar film “Turning Red” (on Disney+ March 11) especially tricky. Because that’s the idea behind this sometimes heartwarming but wayward coming-of-age movie, which toes the line between truthfully representing a Chinese family, flaws and all, and indulging stereotypes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Jenny Hval Makes Ideas Sing
description: On “Classic Objects,” the Norwegian songwriter and novelist shows where simple stories can lead.
content: For many artists, self-consciousness is almost an enemy: a barrier against free-flowing inspiration, a choke point for creativity. But the prolific Norwegian artist Jenny Hval — a singer, songwriter, musician, producer, poet, video director and novelist — treats self-consciousness as a constant, even welcome companion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Elsa Klensch, Face of Fashion on CNN, Dies at 89
description: She was one of the cable channel’s early stars, covering designers, models and trends in a weekly show that brought the industry to a mass television audience.
content: Elsa Klensch, who for two decades produced and hosted the fashion news program “Style With Elsa Klensch” on CNN, becoming one of the cable channel’s early stars, died on March 4 at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Rivian Pares Delivery Targets for 2022, Citing Supply Problems
description: The company said it expected to produce only 25,000 electric vehicles this year, adding a new cloud to its outlook only months after a hot I.P.O.
content: Rivian, which has had a rocky ride in the stock market after a blockbuster initial public offering, cast a further shadow over its outlook on Thursday, reporting that supply chain problems could severely constrain its production of electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Help Wanted
description: John Westwig, a software engineer with New York Times Games, encourages solvers to change careers.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — UPDATE: I have added a comment about 47D in the Tricky Clues section. It is indeed tricky, but there is really only one answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Justice Dept. names a director to pursue cases of Covid-19 relief fraud.
description: President Biden had pledged to name a chief prosecutor to go after “criminals who stole billions in relief money.”
content: The Justice Department named Kevin Chambers on Thursday to lead its efforts to pursue cases of fraud and attempted fraud related to at least $8 billion in Covid-19 relief funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Carlos Barbosa-Lima, 77, Dies; Expanded Classical Guitar’s Reach
description: A virtuoso since his teenage years, he performed concerts that ranged from classical repertory to Brazilian music to the Beatles and Broadway.
content: Carlos Barbosa-Lima, who was a virtuoso on classical guitar while still a teenager in Brazil and then spent a lifetime expanding the instrument’s possibilities, bringing classical techniques and sensibilities to his arrangements of Gershwin, the Beatles and especially the music of his fellow Brazilian Antônio Carlos Jobim, died on Feb. 23 at a hospital in São Paulo. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
title: U.S. Says North Korea Is Testing a New Intercontinental Missile
description: The missile, first displayed in 2020, was tested twice in recent days. While it is unclear whether it can reach the U.S., it poses a new military challenge to President Biden in the midst of the Ukraine war.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House said on Thursday that North Korea had begun testing a new intercontinental ballistic missile in recent days, and that American forces were putting their missile defense units in Asia in a state of “enhanced readiness” for what they expect will be another launch intended to demonstrate the range of the new missile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: “Drive to Survive” is back, as is a dark Amazon comedy about the afterlife.
content: ‘Corporate’When to watch: Now, on Paramount+.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu and Magdalena Chodownik
title: ‘You Just Have to Open the Door and Help People’: Poland’s Tourism Industry Aids Refugees
description: As Ukrainians flood into Poland, the travel industry has become part of an effort to supply transportation, accommodations and more to people fleeing the Russian invasion.
content: Tourism in Poland’s historic city of Lublin was in a deep off-season lull last month when Russia invaded neighboring Ukraine, sending tens of thousands of people fleeing across the country’s eastern border, about 60 miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Russia’s War Is Raising Gas Prices and Roiling Financial Markets
description: The price of gasoline is climbing and the markets are adjusting to gloomier prospects as the war in Ukraine grinds on.
content: It’s getting to the point where you’re better off filling up your gas tank in the morning because the price will be higher by the time you drive home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Nelson W. Aldrich Jr., Dissector of Old Money, Dies at 86
description: In books and articles, he unsparingly scrutinized an American aristocracy that he knew intimately.
content: Nelson W. Aldrich Jr., an author and magazine editor who unsparingly scrutinized his fellow heirs to America’s aristocracy, primarily in “Old Money: The Mythology of Wealth in America,” which one reviewer called “a self-help book for those who have too much,” died on Tuesday at his home in North Stonington, in southeastern Connecticut. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Child Vaccine Confusion
description: It’s been a confusing couple of months for parents.
content: For American parents with young children, it’s been a frustrating and confusing couple of months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: An Urgent Mission for Literary Translators: Bringing Ukrainian Voices to the West
description: A wartime effort to quickly translate work by Ukrainian novelists, poets and historians is underway — a project as political as it is cultural, authors and translators say.
content: As Russian forces breached the border with Ukraine late last month, Kate Tsurkan issued an urgent call for help on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Ali Watkins
title: She Killed Two Women. At 83, She Is Charged With Dismembering a Third.
description: Harvey Marcelin was charged with murder after a head was found in her Brooklyn apartment. Officials said it belonged to a dismembered body discovered in a shopping cart.
content: An 83-year-old Brooklyn woman convicted twice of killing women she lived with was charged with murder on Thursday, after investigators found a head in her apartment that, officials said, belonged to a body discovered in a shopping cart last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: A Potential Rarity in American Politics: A Fair Congressional Map
description: This year’s congressional map, despite continued gerrymandering, is poised to have a nearly equal number of districts that lean Democratic and Republican.
content: For years, America’s congressional map favored Republicans over Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: ‘Inadequate’ Security Led to Deaths of 3 Americans in Kenya Attack, Report Finds
description: The inquiry also found shortcomings in the sharing of intelligence before the deadly assault by the Shabab in 2020.
content: WASHINGTON — A series of security lapses and an “inadequate focus” on threats on the ground helped lead to a deadly assault on a sprawling military base in Kenya in 2020 that killed three Americans, a Pentagon investigation has concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: New Vaccine Findings Pose Tough Questions for Parents of Young Children
description: The F.D.A. temporarily halted efforts to authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for young children amid several unexpected findings. The coming weeks should bring clarity.
content: For American parents, particularly those with young children, the last couple of months have been dizzying and beyond frustrating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Iraqi minister says high oil prices, if they last, could speed the shift to E.V.s.
description: Whatever the short-term benefits for producers, the market upheaval could accelerate the transition away from oil, he says.
content: HOUSTON — Even with boycotts upending supplies from Russia, major oil-producing countries are likely to hold the line on output for now, keeping prices high and reaping the benefits. But that course could prove detrimental in the long run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: BTS performs live in Seoul for the first time in over two years.
description: The K-pop group returned to the stage in South Korea on Thursday, although fans were not allowed to cheer, scream or sing along because of Covid restrictions.
content: SEOUL — Elated fans of BTS gathered on Thursday for the K-pop group’s first live concert in South Korea in over two years, an event that was expected to draw as many as 15,000 people — despite Covid restrictions that barred cheering, screaming or singing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: They Boil Snow for Water, With Death in the Air
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, March 10, 2022.
content: “If somebody dies in your family, just put the body outside, cover it, tie up the hands and the legs and leave it outside.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘All My Friends Hate Me’ Review: Party Animals
description: Things turn nasty when a peculiar stranger infiltrates a reunion of college pals in this clever horror-comedy.
content: Cringe comedy hurtles toward psychological horror in “All My Friends Hate Me,” Andrew Gaynord’s delicious, fearless dive into age-related angst and chronic insecurity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: I’ve never really understood readers who say they don’t like memoirs. For one thing, the genre theoretically comes closer than any other to granting us access to another mind on the page — the very reason so many readers turn to literature in the first place. For another, memoirs aren’t one thing: In subject and style and subjectivity, there are as many kinds of memoirs as there are kinds of writers. If you say you don’t like memoirs, you might as well say you don’t like books, or people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: House Passes $1.5 Trillion Spending Bill as Democrats Drop Covid Aid
description: Facing disputes over how to cover the cost of the pandemic response effort, Democrats dropped it rather than jeopardize legislation that includes aid for Ukraine and other top priorities.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday passed a sprawling $1.5 trillion federal spending bill that includes a huge infusion of aid for war-torn Ukraine and money to keep the government funded through September, after jettisoning a package to fund President Biden’s new Covid-19 response effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: In Democratic Bastion, Liberal Rhetoric Is Out. ‘Affordability’ Is In.
description: In the first budget address of his second term, Gov. Philip Murphy responded to New Jersey voters’ discontent at a time of surging gas costs and high taxes.
content: Gas prices are soaring. The war in Ukraine has rattled the stock market. And, months ahead of midterm elections, voters in key suburban swing districts in New Jersey are restive, contributing to increased dissatisfaction with the state’s Democratic leader, Gov. Philip D. Murphy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: uncouth
description: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word uncouth has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 4 in “Public Displays of Resignation: Saying ‘I Quit’ Loud and Proud” by Emma Goldberg:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Russia, Where All the News Is Fake
description: The country has become a dystopian paragon of corrupted information.
content: We are only as good as the information we get. Only as grounded, as enlightened, as capable of forming rational opinions about our political leaders and making intelligent decisions about our lives. If we’re fed lies, we’re lost. If we subsist on fiction, we dwell in a fantasyland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘This Space Between Us’ Review: A Do-Gooder Faces a Chorus of Resistance
description: Peter Gil-Sheridan’s comedy for Keen Company raises a range of topical issues but fails to cover new ground.
content: Liberals are often criticized for their hand-wringing and failure to walk the walk. But the progressive lawyer at the center of Peter Gil-Sheridan’s “This Space Between Us” intends to lead a life of purpose. “Maybe we could all stand to feel a little more guilty,” he says, without telling us exactly why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Surging U.S. Inflation Raises Stakes as War Pushes Up Prices
description: Consumer Price Index inflation has been boosted by gas prices but also by increases across a wide variety of products and services.
content: Prices climbed at the fastest pace in decades in the month leading up to the war in Ukraine, underlining the high stakes facing the United States — along with many developed economies — as the conflict promises to drive costs higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Recap: Q Is the Worst Friend Ever
description: Everyone’s favorite omnipotent being is back to reveal yet another alternate universe. But this time, he’s not giving out an education.
content: “Show them a world of their own making and they ask you what you’ve done,” John de Lancie’s Q asks Jean-Luc Picard at the top of the second episode of this season’s “Picard.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer, Lisa Friedman and David Gelles
title: As War Rages, a Struggle to Balance Energy Crunch and Climate Crisis
description: Rising oil prices and increased demand for expanded production come at a time when scientists say nations must sharply cut the use of fossil fuels.
content: As the world reels from spikes in oil and gas prices, the fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has laid bare a dilemma: Nations remain extraordinarily dependent on fossil fuels and are struggling to shore up supplies precisely at a moment when scientists say the world must slash its use of oil, gas and coal to avert irrevocable damage to the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word Play: The Winners of Our 9th Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Contest
description: Thank you to the nearly 1,500 students who participated this year. Check out the winning videos to learn 13 new words.
content: At a moment when word games are in the spotlight in The New York Times and in classrooms, we offer you a delightful way to add some new words to your vocabulary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Harris, in Poland, Seeks to Present United Front Against Russia
description: Vice President Kamala Harris visited Warsaw a day after U.S. officials said they were blindsided by Poland’s offer to provide jet fighters to Ukraine. Washington rejected it, fearing it could escalate the conflict.
content: WARSAW — Vice President Kamala Harris called Thursday for an investigation into whether Russia had committed war crimes in Ukraine during a visit to a key NATO ally that has taken in more than one million refugees from the invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Fear’ Review: Stranger in a Strange Land
description: The arrival of an African refugee upends a Bulgarian town in Ivaylo Hristov’s pointed tale of xenophobia.
content: At the beginning of “Fear,” the dominant feeling is loneliness. In a coastal town in Bulgaria, shot in somber, expressive black and white, a middle-aged woman named Svetla (Svetlana Yancheva) leads a life that seems to shrink before our eyes. The school where she had been teaching shuts down, leaving her unemployed. A widow, she visits her husband’s grave, buys a few eggs on credit at a small grocery and engages in some desultory banter with a group of soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Stellantis stops car shipments to and from Russia.
description: The automaker has been making delivery vans in Russia, but its chief has said production is likely to halt because of a lack of parts.
content: Stellantis, the maker of Jeep, Fiat and Peugeot vehicles, has suspended exports of cars from Russia and imports of vehicles into the country, the company said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ulrich
title: Porsche Taycan and Audi e-Tron GT: An Electric Family Tree
description: The two cars share some corporate technology but stand out in different ways. Another trait they share? Price tags mostly in six figures.
content: As far as we can tell, Henry Ford and other auto pioneers made no attempt to imitate the nostalgic clopping of hooves or the smell of, er, hay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: The Graying of Samuel L. Jackson
description: In “The Last Days of Ptolemy Grey,” on Apple TV+, an actor known for his intensity takes on a character living in a fog.
content: Casting Samuel L. Jackson as a man in his 90s with dementia is a bold choice. Is there any actor more defined by his command, his cool, his razor-sharpness? It’s like telling Bill Murray not to be funny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: ‘From the Dustbin of History,’ a Photo Archive of the Jim Crow South
description: “O.N. Pruitt’s Possum Town” captures the soul — and soullessness — of a Mississippi town in the first half of the 20th century.
content: A young Black “manservant” for a white family, who called him “Humpy” because of a back deformity. A Ku Klux Klan march down Main Street circa 1922. Overall-clad men at the construction site of the Magnolia Bowl football stadium in 1933. Minstrel shows, baptisms, carnivals and lynchings. In his portrait studio and out in the world, Otis Noel Pruitt used his camera to bear witness to the soul and soullessness of Columbus, Miss., in the first half of the 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Behind the Scenes, Billionaires Shape French Presidential Campaign
description: In a nation with strict political finance laws, control over the news media has provided an avenue for the very rich to influence elections, this one more than ever.
content: PARIS — The face of President Emmanuel Macron’s possibly fiercest rival in France’s coming election is not on any campaign poster. He has not given a single speech. His name will not be on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Brief Encounters With a Micro Miniskirt
description: A low-rise skirt by Miu Miu went viral last month. Here, three perspectives on wearing it.
content: The Miu Miu skirt is so short that it seems to have no end. For the last two weeks, it has made nearly daily appearances: on the covers of magazines, on the bodies of celebrities and influencers, and as the subject of articles about its reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Do You Still Love the Walkman?
description: Some people love technology that the rest of us see as obsolete junk.
content: Sony’s latest versions of the Walkman, the pioneering portable music player first released in 1979, are nothing like the original cassette player that came with foam headphones. Instead the latest Walkman is a digital music player that costs $1,600 or $3,200.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Damien Cave
title: Australia Asks: How Far Is Too Far in Making China a Campaign Weapon?
description: Australia’s conservative government has claimed, without evidence, that the political opposition would cozy up to Beijing. To many, it has crossed a red line.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — A group of middle-aged Chinese Australians logged onto Zoom to step, kick and punch through their regular exercise class one day late last month. Then they lingered online to despair at the government’s attempt to turn China into a campaign weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: ISIS Names a New Leader, but Says Little About Him
description: The terrorist group announced its new leader as Abu al-Hasan al-Hashimi al-Qurashi, but gave no information about his background or true identity.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Islamic State on Thursday announced that it has a new leader, but provided little information on the true identity or background of the man who will now oversee the global terrorist organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Ultrasound’ Review: Trapped in a Murky Mystery
description: This genre hybrid opens on a dark, stormy night, takes a turn into a narrative maze only to dead end despite some promising kinks.
content: One of the attractions of contemporary puzzle movies — with their ambiguities and labyrinths, unreliable narrators and storytelling thickets — is that their complexities are by turns beguiling and confounding but also familiar. Life takes some navigating, and so do Christopher Nolan movies; capitalism is dehumanizing, just like in the Wachowskis’ “Matrix” series. The stories may be bummers, but at least you’ll have fun putting all their jagged pieces together or just savoring their inscrutable depths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Madeleine Ngo
title: Uncertainty for Biden’s Covid Plan After Aid Is Dropped From Spending Bill
description: The $15.6 billion emergency aid package was stripped amid disputes over how to pay for it, injecting uncertainty into the president’s pandemic response plan.
content: WASHINGTON — Faced with Republican resistance after asking for billions of additional dollars to keep fighting the coronavirus, the Biden administration recently supplied Congress with a chart showing how much money it had left for testing, therapeutics and vaccines. It was filled with zeros.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Sally Schmitt, Trend-Setting Restaurateur, Dies at 90
description: She founded the French Laundry in the Napa Valley with her husband, Don, and is often cited as a pioneer in California cuisine.
content: Sally Schmitt, who with her husband, Don, opened the French Laundry, the now famous restaurant in the Napa Valley of California, in 1978, and in doing so helped solidify the valley as a food-and-wine destination and start a culinary movement built on seasonal local ingredients, died on Saturday at her home in Philo, Calif. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: How Comfortably Can You Speak Your Mind at School?
description: Do you feel you can freely share your opinions on hot-button issues in your classes? Or do you sometimes hold back for fear that someone might criticize what you say?
content: Have you recently been in a classroom discussion where someone voiced an unpopular viewpoint? How was it received by students? By the teacher?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Businesses Assail Texas Move to Classify Care for Trans Teens as ‘Child Abuse’
description: A new ad signed by dozens of big companies warns, “Discrimination is bad for business.”
content: More than 60 major businesses, including household names in technology and retail, have signed onto a new advertising campaign in Texas protesting a move by the state’s governor to label as “child abuse” medical treatments that are widely considered to be the standard of care for transgender teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: 4 Falsehoods Russians Are Told About the War
description: Russia’s disinformation machine is working in overdrive inside its own borders.
content: Russia’s international disinformation campaign seemed to flounder in the early days of the invasion, as narratives about Ukrainian bravery dominated the internet. But in Russia, the country’s propaganda machine was busy churning out a deluge of misinformation aimed at its own citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Russia is slowly making gains but the destruction is growing.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Spirit-Frontier merger could hurt airline competition, legislators say.
description: A group of progressive senators and House members urged federal officials to scrutinize the plan, saying it could harm travelers and workers.
content: A group of progressive lawmakers wants federal officials to scrutinize the proposed merger of Spirit Airlines and Frontier Airlines over concerns that the combination could prove anti-competitive and hurt customers and workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Hunt for Oligarchs’ Money
description: More Russian billionaires are hit with sanctions, and their advisers face greater scrutiny.
content: Britain imposed severe new sanctions today on seven Russian billionaires it said have ties to Vladimir Putin, including the aluminum magnate Oleg Deripaska and Roman Abramovich, the owner of the soccer club Chelsea F.C. It’s part of a widening crackdown on Russian oligarchs, which also includes greater scrutiny of the investment, law and lobbying firms that help these billionaires manage their wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: The Labor Department wants to investigate crypto in retirement plans.
description: Cryptocurrencies aren’t widely used in workplace retirement plans, but the department worries about separating “the facts from the hype.”
content: Shortly after the Biden administration announced that it was taking steps toward regulating cryptocurrencies, the Department of Labor issued a message of its own: Crypto doesn’t belong in most employees’ retirement accounts — and the department intends to investigate some plans that already offer the option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: When a School Desegregates, Who Gets Left Behind?
description: One district’s attempt to integrate has led to unexpected criticism.
content: School districts that actively desegregate their students are still an anomaly. Only an estimated 59 school districts in the country currently take significant action to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are winding down in Russia.
description: At the end of 2021, Goldman Sachs had more than $700 million in exposure to Russia, just a sliver of its total operations. Russia was not among JPMorgan’s top 20 markets.
content: Goldman Sachs on Thursday became the first big American bank to say it would exit Russia after Western governments imposed a raft of sanctions intended to cripple its economy. Hours later, JPMorgan Chase, the biggest bank in the United States, said it was winding down there, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: What a Power Cutoff Could Mean for Chernobyl’s Nuclear Waste
description: With no working reactors, there is no risk of a meltdown. But the ruins from the 1986 disaster still pose considerable dangers.
content: The long-defunct Chernobyl plant in Ukraine is completely dependent on outside sources of electricity. So when that power is cut, as Ukrainian officials and the International Atomic Energy Agency say it has been by Russian troops, problems can result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About Ignoring Text Messages, Sharing Their Lives Online and a “Melting Man”
description: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
content: This week on The Learning Network, one of our writing prompts asked teenagers if it is acceptable to ignore texts and other forms of online communication. We also wanted to know how much of their personal lives they share online. And, as one of our Picture Prompts, we invited them to interpret an image of a liquefying figure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Gold’ Review: Dry Heave
description: Zac Efron stars in an unrelentingly miserable post-apocalyptic movie from the Australian actor and director Anthony Hayes.
content: There’s a type of blunt, brutal fable about men and avarice that has been reworked every decade or so since Erich von Stroheim’s silent epic “Greed” was released in 1924. The middling “Gold,” directed by Anthony Hayes from a screenplay he wrote with Polly Smyth (who is also Hayes’s spouse), is one of them. It rides on the dusty coattails of touchstones of the genre: think “The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,” the “Mad Max” franchise and “There Will Be Blood.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Democrats Find Their Inflation Villains: Vladimir Putin and Big Oil
description: With the U.S. battling high oil prices and facing a dangerous confrontation with Russia, the Democratic Party is coalescing around a new message for the midterms.
content: Democrats have a new strategy for dealing with the political impact of high gasoline prices: Blame it on Putin and Big Oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: LeBron Fandom, and the Making of a Friendship in ‘King James’
description: Rajiv Joseph’s new play, which chronicles the bond between two LeBron James fans over 12 years, is having its world premiere at Steppenwolf in Chicago.
content: CHICAGO — When the actor Glenn Davis talks about his new play, “King James,” he gets some variation on this question: “So, are you playing LeBron James?”

title: It’s a Good Time to Be a Relationship Coach
description: Whether dating or divorcing, people are turning to coaches for their goal-oriented approach, which can deliver structure and achievements at a time when both may be lacking.
content: Sofia Montijo’s first two-hour phone call with Samantha Burns in November 2020 was spent assessing Ms. Montijo’s love life.

title: A Waiter. A Cab Driver. An Engineer: The U.S. Fighters Bound for Ukraine
description: Ukrainians across the U.S., many of whom have never fired a weapon, have put their lives on hold to defend their homeland.
content: Last week, Yuriy Blazhkevych, a taxi driver who lives in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, stood in his garage, scrolling through images of Ukraine on his phone that showed buildings with blasted-out windows, tanks rolling over cars and people fleeing for their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: ‘Carpeaux Recast’: A Sculptural Gem With a Knotty Back Story
description: A show at the Metropolitan Museum, organized around a single marble sculpture, re-examines works of art representing slavery and abolition.
content: Traditional museums are literally conservative places. They’re built to freeze objects in time, to shield them from change. Too often the conservative impulse extends to institutional thinking, which leaves cultural ideals and values embodied in objects embalmed in Beauty and Greatness, and left at that.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Lawrence V. Ray was indicted after a New York magazine story uncovered his cultlike hold over his daughter’s college friends and others.
content: One day in 2018, Lawrence V. Ray went looking for a woman he knew — a woman he felt was “slipping from his control,” a prosecutor said Thursday during an opening statement in Mr. Ray’s trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A Coach’s Homophobic Taunt Forces Him to Reconsider the Weight of Words
description: Russell Turner, the U.C. Irvine men’s basketball coach, kept his job, but rethought his place in a male sports culture that often includes casual homophobia, sexism and racism.
content: IRVINE, Calif. — Russell Turner was on top of the world three years ago when he eased into a chair in front of a microphone. Sure, the men’s basketball team he was coaching, U.C. Irvine, had lost decisively to Oregon in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament. But the Anteaters had won a school-record 31 games that season, including their first tournament victory with an upset of Kansas State. There was also interest from Pac-12 and Mountain West Conference schools about hiring him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Son and My Husband Are Fighting. Help!
description: A reader seeks advice about repairing the relationship between two loved ones without damaging her own.
content: My son (29) and my husband (his stepfather of 20 years) had a tense and unproductive argument two months ago, during which my husband refused to hear my son’s side or let him respond. Afterward my son left the house abruptly and said he wouldn’t return. My husband still focuses on the content of their conversation, rather than his behavior. My son also said that I never stood up for him with his stepfather. Our communication has dwindled to a slow trickle of texts. I have always been the peacemaker and tend to believe that things work out eventually. But my son says: Not this time! I am hurt and paralyzed with fear about how to handle this. Help!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Ada Petriczko
title: Thirteen governors want the federal public health emergency extended beyond April.
description: In a letter to the U.S. health secretary, the governors, all Democrats, said they needed more time to prepare for when the emergency expires, taking with it federal resources that state programs depend on.
content: Thirteen Democratic state governors wrote to Health and Human Services Secretary Xavier Becerra this week, urging him to extend the country’s public health emergency declaration for at least another three months beyond its scheduled expiration in April.

title: Guatemalan Women Face Up to 10 Years in Prison Under New Abortion Law
description: The measure, which is expected to be signed into law by Guatemala’s conservative president within weeks, would impose the harshest punishments for abortion of almost any country in Latin America.
content: Guatemalan lawmakers have passed a sweeping new bill mandating up to 10 years of jail time for women who obtain abortions, explicitly banning same-sex marriage and preventing schools from teaching about sexual diversity.

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Adam Project’ Review: Back Talk to the Future
description: Ryan Reynolds plays a time traveling wise cracker in Shawn Levy’s science fiction adventure.
content: Early in “The Adam Project,” a pipsqueak asthmatic named Adam (Walker Scobell) and his golden retriever gallivant through the woods among shimmering falling debris. The cause of the wreckage, Adam learns, is a time jet that was crash landed by his older self (Ryan Reynolds) traveling from the future. This is pure ’80s sci-fi pastiche for the ages. Add a few flying saucer chases, cook up a quickie solution to the grandfather paradox and this movie might have fallen at the intersection of “E.T.” and “Back to the Future.”
